DOC.HEAD: US Effort To Achieve Noriega's Departure Ended Last Month
With AM-US-Panama Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration carried out secret contacts with a lawyer for Panama's Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as recently as last month in hope of persuading Noriega to step down, the State Department said Wednesday. The contacts were disclosed in a State Department fact sheet outlining U.S. diplomatic efforts to resolve Panama's political crisis. The lawyer, who was not identified, told Bush administration officials in October he was authorized to discuss Noriega's departure. After the U.S. officials ask for a specific proposal, the attorney promised to consult with Noriega and return in a week. But, last month, Noriega's lawyer advised the U.S. officials that he had been unsuccessful in obtaining any flexibility from Noriega and said he was under instructions to have no further contacts with the administration, according to the fact sheet. In early 1988, after Noriega was indicted on drug trafficking charges, the State Department had attempted to negotiate his departure from Panama but he suspended the talks at the last moment just when it seemed an agreement was within reach. That proposal called for Noriega to leave Panama in August 1988 and for steps toward the restoration of democratic rule.
